text_paragraphs: Information Note on the Court’s case-law
July 1994
Vendittelli v. Italy - 14804/89
Judgment 18.7.1994
Article 6
Article 6-1
Reasonable time
Length of criminal proceedings: no violation
Article 1 of Protocol No. 1
Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1
Peaceful enjoyment of possessions
Continuation of sequestration of a flat: violation

[This summary is extracted from the Court’s official reports (Series A or Reports of Judgments and Decisions). Its formatting and structure may therefore differ from the Case-Law Information Note summaries.]
I.	ARTICLE 6 § 1 OF THE CONVENTION ("REASONABLE TIME")
A.	Period to be taken into consideration
Beginning: confirmation by magistrate of placing of seals on flat.
End: point at which Court of Appeal's decision became final.
Result: four years, five months and ten days.
B.	Relevant criteria
Complexity of the case: none.
Applicant's conduct: had contributed to prolonging the proceedings in the Court of Appeal.

Authorities' conduct: magistrate's court — had taken eleven months and fifteen days to notify its decision, but as applicant had been present when it was delivered, he could have been expected to obtain a copy of the judgment himself and draw up his grounds of appeal; Court of Appeal — judgment never served, but that failure had had no effect on length of proceedings since matter was one of taking formal note of an amnesty.
Overall length of trial not excessive.
Conclusion: no violation (five votes to four).
II.	ARTICLE 1 OF PROTOCOL NO. 1
A.	Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 taken together with Article 6 § 1 of the Convention
Sequestration: measure ancillary to the criminal proceedings, which had not contravened Article 6 § 1.
Conclusion: no violation (five votes to four).
B.	Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 taken alone
Impugned measure:
(a) had been provided for by law, being designed not to deprive applicant of his property but only to prevent him from using it - second paragraph of Article 1 consequently applicable;
(b) had pursued a legitimate aim, namely to preserve evidence of offence and prevent any aggravation of it;
(c) had no longer been justified, at least as soon as the Court of Appeal's judgment had become final - had placed a disproportionate burden on applicant.
Conclusion: violation (unanimously).
III.	Article 50 of the Convention
Failure to comply with time-limit laid down in the Rules of Court for filing claims for just satisfaction.
Conclusion: claims dismissed (unanimously).
